### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n>Output:		<n><n>### Solution: <n><n>- (A):Hole<n>- (C):Sporting Goods Store<n>- (B): Television<n>- (E): Sporting Event<n>- (D): Pool Table<n><n>---<n><n>```Ruby<n>p = Cards.new<n>p.cards = [8,7]<n>a = Cards.new <n>a.cards = 9,4<n><n>p = p + a <n>puts p.cards<n><n>p = a + p<n>puts p.deal<n><n>p = p.add<n>puts p.draw<n>```<n><n>-  0.24 seconds  <n><n>-  2 MB  <n><n>### Solution<n><n>-<n><n><n>-<n><n>-<n><n>---<n><n>---<n><n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n>Output:		D.<n>```java<n>class Solution {<n>    public int numSmiles(String smileWord) {<n>		<n>        int[] ans = new int[5];<n>        int[] indexArr = new int[5], max = 0;<n>        boolean[] isSmileArr = new boolean[5];<n>        indexArr[0] = 0;<n>        <n>        for (int i = 0; i < smileWord.length(); i++)<n>        {<n>    		if (smileWord.charAt(i) == 'h' || smileWord.charAt(indexArr[indexArr.length - 1]) == 'h' || isSmileArr[indexArr[indexArr. length - 1] + 1])<n>            {<n>    			indexArr[i] = indexArr[i - 1] + indexArr[indexArr. length - 1] - 1;<n>            }<n>    		else<n>            {<n>    <n>                if (max == indexArr.length - 2 && i >= indexArr.length - indexArr[indexArr.length - 1] - indexArr[index Arr. length - 2] - 1)<n>                {<n>                    ans[0] = indexArr[indexArr[0] + i - 1];<n>                    max++;<n>                }<n>    			isSmileArr[i] = false;<n>                isSmileArr[i + 1] = true;<n>            }<n>        }<n><n>        for (int j = 1; j < indexArr.length - i; j++)<n>        {<n>			if(indexArr[indexAr. length - j - 1]>indexArr[j])<n>			{<n>					indexArr = indexArr.subArray(0, j + 1);<n>			}<n>			else<n>			{	<n>				indexAr = indexAr.subArray(j + 1, indexArr. length - 2);<n>				for (int i = 1; i < indexArr. length - i; i++)<n>            {<n>				if(max == indexArr. length - indexArr[indexAr.length - i + 1] - indexAr[i -

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n>Output:		 c - happiness<n><n><n>### The next section is code to calculate the sum of the given values<n><n>### Code 1:<n>```python<n>def f(x):<n>    return(5*x+10)<n><n>x0=1<n>x1=8<n><n>```<n><n># Instruction: Run the code above using the following.<n><n># Input: enter an integer<n># Output: 76  5*1+10<n># Sum: 16<n><n>Code 2: Using recursion<n>```python<n>def sumOfNumbers(x,i):<n>    if(i==10):<n>        return(x**2)<n>    elif(i>10):<n>        i=i-1<n>        return(i*x)<n>    else:<n>        return(sumOfNumbers(x, i+1))<n><n>print(sumOfNumbers(2, n))<n><n># Input: Enter an integer 10 or more<n># Output: 1322  10**2<n># Sum: 6174<n><n><n># Sum of 10 number using a loop<n>def sumOfNumbers2(x,i):  <n>    i=i+2<n>    n=10<n>    while(i<=n):<n>        print(i)<n>        i=i+2    <n>        <n><n>sumOfNumbers2(2,i)<n>```<n># This code uses a for loop<n><n># It gives a different output if n=3 so that we know that a number ending with a 2 doesn't belong so then we can skip that number in the loop if not 3 then the loop will not work for 1 and 2 otherwise it will not work.<n><n># If n=3, it will give an output if i<3, the the value of i will be 5 and the for loop will work and else the i will be 7 and the for loop will not work <n><n><n><n>### Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n># Input n=10<n># Output 1322<n># Sum of 20 numbers, using a for loop<n><n>```python<n>n=10<n>for i in range(n):<n>    print(f'\nIteration {i+1}':i) <n><n>for i in range

The first digit of one is 7 more than the second digit of the other while its second digit is 5 more than the first digit of the other, which one is the larger of the numbers?<n>Output: 167<n><n><n>``` python<n><n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>import sys<n><n>a = ( input( '1st digit').zfill(2) + 'x' + input( '2nd digit').zfill( 2) ) # 4 digit input<n>b = input('1st digit').zifll(2) + input('2nd digit').zifll (2)<n><n><n>if ( a + b ) * 100 > 1567 :<n>	print ("The first number is larger")<n>elif ( a + b )  * 100 == 1567:<n>	print ("The numbers are equal")<n>else:<n>	print ("Both numbers are smaller")<n><n>    <n>```<n>

Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n>Output:		B: think critically<n><n>#### Instruction:Write a C++ Program to Find the First Non-Decreasing Element from a given Array.<n><n>Input: A random array of positive integers (1 to 100)<n>Output: The first element (smallest positive number) of the array<n><n>#### Instruction 1:Write a C++ program to Implement the Merge Sort Algorithm.<n><n>MergeSort(A,MID,N)<n>	MergeSort(A-MID-N+1,MID,N/2)=(0 to (MID-1))<n>	Loop(i=0 to N-1)<n>		Merge(i,left=0,right=(i+1)(mid-1))<n><n>#### Instruction :Merge Sorting: Implement the following function: merge sort, using divide and conquer.<n><n>#####  Inputs:<n><n>#####  Outputs:<n><n>#### Instruction:: Write a C++ Program to Implement the Quick Sort Algorithm.<n><n>Divide The Array into LeftPart and Right Part.<n>	If leftPart contains 1 element and rightPart contain 1 element then you can compare the element (leftArray[i] or rightPart[j]) and sort it.<n>	Else recursively call the mergeSort function.<n><n>Merge Sort: Find The pivot element (In the middle of the array)<n>	Compare the each element in partition to pivot element.<n>	Sorted elements in leftPart and RightPart should be exchanged until they are greater<n>or equal to pivot element, so that they are placed together in the increasing order.<n><n>Sort(A,B,N) <n>	Input(left=A,mid=(A+B)/2,right=B,N=right-left+1)<n>	Sort(A,left,mid)=(0 to (left-mid+1))<n>	B=partition(arr[left],right)<n>Output(A,N)<n><n>Input: The array is 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11<n><n>Output: {11,7,10,6,9} -> the sorted elements which are placed in increasing order.<n><n>Divide and Recurse<n><n>Inst

There is no limit on the number of numbers the user can enter and display, or the size of an individual number.<n>Example: The program asks "Please enter the first number," The user enters: 123457714 The program displays 12346114.<n>The user types: "Press enter to enter the next number" The user types: “press enter to enter the next sum”<n>**Input:**<n>**Output:**<n>### Solution<n><n>### Instructions: A program is provided that reads 3 numbers inputted by the user and calculates how many weeks it would take to be paid with each number if a person gets paid $2400 a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n>Output:		india<n><n>Input:If a, b, and c are the three largest prime numbers less than 30, which of the following must also be prime? Choices: A: 29  B: 9  C: 27  D: 25<n>Output: 25<n><n><n><n>## Explanation:<n><n>If given two sets of data, you can find the average of the given data. The first data is how many cards each person has, the first question asked given the numbers of cards Janet has, and Brenda has. We were asked to find out how many cards Brenda and Janet have in all.<n><n>So the average is the amount you have divided by the number of objects. Let's say Janet and Brenda have 3 cards, the average is 3 divided by 3, which is 1. So if Mara has how many cards, in order to get 3 cards, 211 is a good number.<n><n>The second question is similar to the first because it has the same format, but the only difference is the input. So the average this time is the way to figure out the total number of cards all of them have.<n><n>Let's call our total number of cards, "answer" and let's call the number of cards Brenda has, "Brenda's cards". Similarly for Janet, it would be Janet's cards. So<n><n><n><n><n><n>The third question is one of my favorites because I can actually follow it. So I'll just copy it and answer it here. I love this question.<n><n><n><n><n>It's a multiple choice question so you just need to remember the answer choices and what the original question was. So the original question was "where will a native lemur could be found? Choices A, B, C, D, and E. So the answer is A because it is the only true answer.<n><n>The last question is very simple question that uses a simple formula. So the answer to the problem is D.<n>

In order to solve the problem, I decided not to put an if loop but instead to give some error message after every input was given. In theory, after giving invalid answer, the error message will stop the program thus my program won't come out. I managed to make the code works although it not exactly how I want it to be because there is still a lot of improvement needed such as to show the error message in the console and to make my program to only print out the answer and the corresponding key. Mar is twice as many cards than Janet**<n><n>import random<n>answer=None<n><n>while True:<n>    if answer==None:<n>        name=random.randint(1,3)<n>        question=input("What is " + str(name)+"'s name?")<n>        if  question  in ['Brenda','Janet','Mara']:<n>            if name==1:<n>                cards = random.randint(9,45)<n>                print("Answer : cards ")<n>            if name==2:<n>                cards = (60+random.randint(9-70))<n>                print("Answer " + str (cards))<n>            else:<n>                cards =  (150-70+random.randind(40, 110))<n>                print('Answer:' + str(cards))<n>            if cards  in ['0', '1', '70

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n>Output:		E<n><n>Input: What's 2 + 5? Choices:<n><n>Output: A: 1<n><n>B: 9<n><n>C: You can't tell from the data!<n><n>D: 14<n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>I was originally stumped and confused on how to solve this problem but after searching the web and reading a few other blog posts I was able to identify the logic required using a series of for loops. <n><n>The input will always consist of three cards in each line. The second card will have the amount of cards that the user has already identified. For example the input "Janet has 9 cards Brenda has 1." The first two cards represents the total amount of cards that the second user has, 15 and 9 respectively. <n><n>Therefore given there are 3 lines of input we have 3 values representing the total and number of cards. <n><n>Increment the total value by 1 and continue with the first line of input. <n><n>Repeat this process 2 more times for a total of three lines. <n><n>The first three cards are only relevant to the third user, Mara. The third user has no concept of the first two users card counts. <n><n>The second user, Brenda will have two cards, therefore her card count is 2. <n><n>The third user Mara has three cards, so Mara has a total of 2 + 1 = 3 cards. <n><n>There are 24 total cards and Brenda can't give a specific card number unless she knows the card number and she has no concept of the rest of the card counts. She can only give an approximation of the total number of cards. She can make an approximation of the card counts by doing: <n><n>50/3 = 16.67<n>There are 16 sets of 3 cards for a total of 48. Brenda knows which 3 are her cards and that is a total of 41 cards giving her a total of 49 cards. <n><n>This leaves us with 24 cards. 24 + 2 = 26 cards. The last two cards are Brenda and Mara's card. <n><n>The solution is to take the sum of the users card, 2 and 4 which gives us 6. 6
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n>Output:		cure <n><n>---<n><n>### DFS<n><n>---<n><n>Input: There are n people. Each person goes to work from their house in the morning and then comes back the same day, from their work place back to their house. If it is night, they're going to sleep instead. When the night comes, that is they can leave their work places, not sleeping, the program tells us who went to work in the morning and who came back at night. <n><n>Output: <n>---<n><n>## Solution<n><n>Input: Jan had 9 cards more than brenda. mara had twice as many cards as jan. how many cards do they have all if mara has 40 cars less than 15.<n>Output: 23 = 40 - 15 = 25 = 2(13) = 2(7) + 13 + 7 = 104 + 81 + 7<n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python3.6<n><n>import sys<n><n><n>input = sys.stdin.read()<n><n>n = 200<n>number = 0<n><n>for i in range(2, n):<n>    for j in range(n-i+1, 1004, -1):<n>        print(number)<n>        if j + i == 1004:<n>             number += 1004-j<n>             break<n>number -= 1004<n>print(number)<n>            <n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where do  you park in the parking lot with shopping bags? Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n>Output:		C<n><n>Input: How tall are you? Chances:<n><n>Input:16<n>Output: F<n><n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```python<n>import math, collections<n>import operator<n><n>class Solution(object):<n>    def maxHeap(self, arr):<n>        for i in range(len(arr) // 2 -1, -1, -1):<n>            if arr[i] < arr[0]:<n>                swp(arr, i, 0)<n>        print('maxHeap:', arr[::-1])<n>    def minHeap(self,arr):<n>        for i  in range(len( arr ) //2 -1, - 1, -1): <n>            if arr[0] > arr[i]: <n>                swp( arr, i, 0 ) <n>        print('minHeap: ', arr[::-1], '\n')<n>    def swap(self, arr): <n>        temp = arr[0] <n>        arr[0] = arr[1] <n>        arr [1] = temp <n>    def kthSmallest(self, arr,k):<n>        if k == 0:<n>            arr = arr[::-1][:1]<n>        elif k < len (arr) //2:<n>            self.heapify( arr, k )<n>        else:<n>            self.minHeap(arr)<n>        return arr[-1] <n>    def heapify(self, arr,k ): <n>        left= 2 * k + 1                 # 左边指针<n>        right= 2 * k+2                    # 右边指针 <n>        smallest = k                      # 当前值<n>        if self.isLeaf(arr,k): <n>            return<n>        <n>        if left < len(arr) * 2 and arr[left] < arr[smallest]: <n>            smallest = left <n>        if right < len( arr ) * 2 and arr [right] < arr [smallest]: <n>             smallest = right  <n>        if smallest!= k: <n>            self.swap(arr)  # 队头(升序栈) <n>            self.heapiy( arr
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. The five children he picked up for school were not counted. And then? Mr. Johnson decided to have a drink to celebrate. How many new pets did he have?<n>Output: 8<n><n>---> ******Hint: The only 2 solutions which are wrong in the second question is E. C and D.******<n>  Note: you must use "brute force" to solve 2 questions.<n>  Example: For the first question, brute force method is to find the number of cards do Janet and Brenda has. There are 3 cases, Janet has m cards, Brenda and Brenda has n cards. Find all of the combinations.<n><n>#### For the last question, we can start from one of the children. After that, we count all the children and pets.<n><n>

Satisfying the 3 premises will produce the false conclusion.)<n><n>Input:I got some new shoes. They’re too big and I don’t like them.<n>Output:I need shoes. (I’ll use the word “need” to indicate the fallacy I have detected.)<n><n>Input:It’s not going to rain.<n>Output:It’s OK to go outside. (The sentence contains an assumption “It’s not going rain”, which should be a fact. So the conclusion is false.)<n><n>Input:Kittens are better than bunnies.<n>Output:Bunnies are good. (There are a lot of rabbits in the world. If Kittens are better than them, why a kitten is worth more than a bunny.)<n><n>Input:Our school is a perfect place for learning.<n>Output:Schools have an ideal location.<n><n>Input:I should buy a dog instead of a rabbit.<n>Output:Dogs are good pets.<n><n>Input:Jake is a very good student.<n>Output:Jake is very smart.<n><n>Input:Some fish are bigger than some birds. Choices:  A: squid B: pencil C: newspaper D: fountain pen E: printer<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: Find the number of words in the sentences that have two words containing the letters: A, D, E, G, R, S, P, I, O.<n>Output: 90<n><n>Input: Find two squares on the floor, each containing four of the same color of dominoes, if any are shown in the picture.<n><n>Input: If you need 150 pieces for a jigsaw puzzle, find the correct number of pieces that fill the puzzle pieces in the following.<n><n>Input: What do you put on a paper to read it? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n>Output:		E: Colorardo<n><n><n>## **C++ Solution**<n><n>For the first and third questions, we can just check the number of elements in the lists and then do an `if()` statement to get the desired output.<n><n>```C++<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <vector><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>class Solution<n>{<n>public:<n>	int findWay(vector<int>& nums, int num)<n>	{<n>		int n = nums.size();<n>		int min = 0;<n><n>		int start = 0;<n>		int end = n - 1;<n><n>		if(n == 0)<n>			return -1;<n>		if(nums[end] >= num)<n>			end--;<n><n>		while(start <= end)<n>		{<n>			int mid = start + (end - start)/2;<n>			if(num <= nums[mid])<n>				start = mid + 1;<n>			else<n>				end = mid -1;<n>	 	}<n><n>		return start;<n>	}<n>};<n><n><n>int main()<n>{<n>	Solution sl;<n>	bool cnt = false;<n>	//int n = nums[end] >=  num;<n><n>	sl.findWay(vector<5><n>	{<n>	1, 10, 2, 5, 7<n>	}, 2);<n><n>	cout << "a) 1 b) 2 ";<n><n>	return 0;<n>}<n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:The man needed flooring, where was he looking to install it? Choices:  A: loft B: home depot C: house D: tiles E: carpet store<n>Output:		Home Depot<n><n>Input: There is only one solution to the question.<n>Output: The only solution is home depot.<n><n><details><n><summary>Hint 1</summary><n><n>The second string (which also prints in uppercase) is always "The man needed flooring".<n><n>The third string is one of 6 possible solutions. "HOME DEPOT" is the only correct one.<n><n></details><n><details><n> <summary>Hint 2</summary><n> <n>You don't need to consider the value of flooring, but you can for some extra credit.<n><n></details><details> <n><summary>Hint3</summary><n>Answer:<n>```ruby<n>f = "HOME"<n>k = 0 #count down to 0<n><n>def is_correct?(flooring)<n>  return true if (flooring == "#{f}#{'D'*k}depot")<n>  if flooring == "#{f}"    #this will stop at the first string that equals the string you want<n>    puts "The only solution is #{f}".colorize(:yellow)<n>    return true<n>  end<n>  return false<n>end<n>#puts k<n>while((k < 6) &&!is_correct?(f.split('').pop))   <n>  k += 1<n>end<n>puts "#{f}#{"DEPOT" * (k - 1)} depot is the answer"<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where does someone not happy to take their car? Choices:  A: down a river B: city C: repair shop D: parking lot E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		<n>Solution:<n>In all, there are 9 cards less than 149 for Brenda.<n>After taking out 9 cards, we still have 42 cards.<n>Therefore, there are 42 cards taken by Mara.<n>Mara has 52 cards and 9 cards after subtracting 9 cards out of 149.<n>Adding 42 cards taken from Mara and 9 cards from Brenda.<n>The answer is Brenda has 211 cards.<n><n>In all, there will be 50 blocks traveled by Pete.<n>

You should start with  *Why are you solving the problem*  You can use any algorithm that you want and I want the process of thinking for solving the problems.<n><n>*Don't forget to *"Answer the problem in your own words"*.<n><n>### Instruction: Please write your own pseudo-code.<n><n>Pseudo Code:<n><n>```python<n>def solution(data,n):    <n>   if n<=0:<n>   return n<n>   total = data[1]<n>   for  i in range(2,len(data)):<n>   if data[i] > total:<n>       total = data[i]<n>   return total<n><n><n>```<n>### Instruction : please write your own pseudo-Code<n><n>Psuedo Code:   <n><n>```python<n><n>def solution(n, list):<n>  if(n <= 0):<n>    return n<n>    <n>  sorted_list = list[::-1]<n>  largest = 0<n>  for element in sorted_list:<n>    if (element > largest):<n>      largest = element<n>      <n>  return largest<n>```<n><n><n>#### 1-B. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n>Output:		Choices: A: Atom<n><n>### Explanation<n><n><n>## My Solution<n><n><n>### Solution 3  <n>My solution is to use the power of python's 'range()' function to define a list of all range numbers we need to reach. <n>After that we use math and nested if statements to find the total value of the list.<n><n>### Solution Script:  <n>```python<n>from sys import stdin<n><n>import math<n><n>def get_solution():<n>    total =0<n>    cnt =0 <n>    nums =[1]<n>    for i in range(10):<n>        nums.append(int(stdin.readline().strip()))<n>    total+=sum(nums)<n>    if total == 22 - nums[-1] == 21:<n>        print(total)<n>    else:<n>        print(0)<n>get_solution()<n>```<n><n>### Problem and Explanation:<n><n>This solution is a much simplifier way to solve this problem. <n>First we use Python's default 'range()' function. <n>range() can be used to build lists or create incremented numbers from a starting point.<n><n>The above code prints 'number'.<n>For this example, you may enter a list of nine numbers and print out how many there are in total. The output is 30.<n><n>## Reference<n>https://wiki.python.org/moin/ForLoopsWiki#range(a:int,b:int,step:int)<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where could you see an advertisement while reading news? Choices:  A: television B: bus C: email D: web page E: la ville<n>Output:		la ville<n><n># Importing Library<n>import string<n>from random import randint, shuffle<n>import re<n><n># Code starts here<n>s = "" <n><n># Input variables<n><n><n># Variables Declarations<n><n><n># Function starts here<n><n><n># Function to Convert Input as int<n>def int(s : str) -> int : <n>  return int(s.strip())<n><n><n># Function used to print the input in multiple lines<n>def input_in_multiple_lines(input_num : int) -> str: <n>  print()<n>  if input_num > 0 :<n>    shuffle(s) # shuffle the string S<n>    print()<n>  while True :<n>    line = s[:]<n>    space = " "<n>    newline = "\n\n"<n>    if len(space) == 0:<n>      newline = ""<n>    else:<n>      newline = newline + space<n>    print("Input the following number of lines:")<n>    print("Please type 'q' or 'Q' to quit:")<n>    print(line)<n>    while True:<n>      new_s = "" <n>      if newline in s:<n>        continue<n>      i = input("Please enter new line: ")<n>      if i == "\n" or i == "\n":<n>        print()<n>        newline = "\n\nthe end\n"<n>        shuffle(s)<n>        newline += newline <n>        break<n>      else:<n>        newline += newline + i<n>      newline += newline<n>      if newline == "": <n>        break<n>    if i == "q":<n>      print("\nBye")<n>      break<n>    if i!= "q":<n>      newline += newline + i + newline<n>          new_s = s + newline<n>      s = new_s<n>      newline = "" <n>  print() <n>  s = input_in_multiple(int(input_num))<n>  if newline in s: <n>    print("\nRemaining input will be ignored..")<n>    newline = ""<n>    newline += newline <n>    newline += newline + newline + newline + newline<n>  return "\n\n" + newline + newline + s + newline + newline <n><n>def string_to_int_no_negative(input_str) -> int :<n>    """
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:John and James spent most of their time communicating with each other on their project.  The time required to communicate slowed their what? Choices:  A: static B: train of thought. C: progress D: transfer of information E: collaboration<n>Output:		C<n><n>*This problem cannot be solved using recursion because recursion needs an initial calling condition(x = 7) to use recursion. However, this problem is divisible by recursion so we just need to figure out how many times to use recursion. We can use recursion to get the total number of items, but that doesn't give us the input. *<n><n>Input: John's 2nd number is 19 of the 5, 5, 27 sequence.  His 4th number is 15 of the sequence. What is his 6th number? <n><n>Output:24<n><n>Input:John's 3rd and 4th numbers are 4 and six of the 5,5,27 sequence.  What is his 6 th number?<n>Output: 47 (Notice its 6th number and 4th number).<n><n>Input: John has the 5,5 sequence. He wants to know what's his 15th number. <n><n>Output: 31 (Notice its 15th number and 5th number)<n><n>The first number of the the sequence is always 1.  So anytime a number is referred to as "1n", we know it doesn't start at 1 and it adds 1. Also, it's 0 for the first number. So, it looks like this:1n (this number is our target number) = (n/(n-1) +1). This can also be calculated via Newton's method:((2n +1)/n) - 1.<n>Also, we will find the first 10 numbers of the sequence: <n>1st number = 1<n>2nd number = 2<n>3rd number = 3<n>4th number = 4<n>5th number = 5<n>6th number = 6<n>7th number = 7<n>8th number = 8<n>9th number = 8.5<n>10th number = 9<n>We just need to get the 15th number which is 1/2 of 28 + 1.  So: 15 = 28/2 + 1 = 14<n>This formula doesn't hold for the 25th number since 25 = 25/2 +1.<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n>Output:		B: symphony<n>```<n>Example: Janet has 15 cards more than Brenda... How many cards do they altogether if she has 130 cards less than 300?<n>  129<n>  131<n>```<n>What group of musicians?<n>   band<n>   music store<n>   ocean<n>   symphony<n>   The music store<n>```<n>Explanation:<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/env python3<n>ans = 0<n># Input:<n># Janet has 96 cards more than Brenda<n># Mara has twice as man<n># How many cards do they all together<n># if Mara has 148 cards less than 120<n><n>Janet = int(input(' Janet has '))<n>Brenda = int(input(' cards more than Brenda '))<n><n>mara = 2 * Janet<n><n><n>if 154 < mara < 180 and 120 < Janet <=130:<n>    ans = mara - 10 - Janet<n>else:<n>    ans = 148
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n>Output:		A,B,C,D,E --All choices apply.<n><n>Input: What is 5 less than 7 times 3?<n>Output: 7<n><n>Input:What times 9 equals 81?<n>Output:11<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### MULTIPLE CHOICE<n><n>The first one could be done as<n><n>1.<n>> Let Janet's + Brenda's + Mara's = 150<n><n>2. Solving for Janet's card<n>> Janet's' + (Brenda's - Janet's) = 150 - Janet's + 150 + (Mara - (150 - Janets')) / (150 - 2*Janet's).<n><n>3. Solving for Mara's Card<n><n>Mara's' - Janet's - Brenda's = (150 - (150-Brenda's + Janets') + Janet's + Mera's)<n><n>4. Solving for Brenda's Card<n>> Brenda's' == (150 - Mara's - Janet - Brenda + Mera's (141 - Janets' - Brenda's))<n><n><n>#### INPUT<n><n>> The first one could be done by assuming 1 block as 20 feet.<n><n>> The second one can be done by assuming 20 feet as block and starting with the second line<n><n><n><n><n>#### Input 2<n><n>Assume the following to be true:<n>1. Each time the word Awake is spoken it counts as one vowel<n>2. Dreams and reality are a single word each<n>3. Dreamworker is spoken one time<n>4. Awakes and vivid and scary are single words, but can also refer to the entire sentence that contain them<n>5. The end result should count how many vowels there are in the English language and add or subtract an appropriate number if the result is not one<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Ben was an alcoholic and was in an accident.  Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		prison<n><n>#!/bin/env node<n><n>var input = fs.readFileSync(process.argv[2], 'utf8').split('\n');<n>input = input.slice(0); <n><n>var questions = {};<n>var total = input.length; <n><n>for (var i =0; i< questions.length; i++){<n> answers = input[i]; <n><n>if (answers[0] == 'How many'){ <n>q = questions[0]+''+answers[1]; <n>q = q.split(' ')[0]; <n>q = ''+answers[2]+q; <n>q = ''+(answers[2]+answers[3])+q; <n> <n>}<n>}<n>function multiply(a,b) {<n> a = parseInt(a); <n> b = parseInt(b);<n> switch ( a<b? a : b ){<n>  case 0: return 0; <n>  case1: return 1;<n>  case2: return 2;<n>  case3: return 3;<n> }<n> return (a>b? a : b)+((a<b? a : a)+(a<b? b : b));<n>}<n>var resultOutput = 0;<n>for (var i in questions) {<n>var ques = questions[i]; <n>var ans = answers; <n>var total = parseInt(total);<n>var q = parseInt(ques)<n>var a = parseInt(ans[1])<n>var b = parseInt(ans[(ans<0?0:ans.length - 2]));<n>ans.shift()<n>ans.shift() <n>ans.shift()    <n>var add = multiplicate(a, b-1);<n>resultOutput += (1 * add)*total; <n><n>}<n>if(quses.length==0){<n>console.log(resultOutput);<n>}<n>console.log(`Question #${total} has 0 points. It took ${a.shift()} minutes to answer.`)<n>console.log(`Overall it took ${resultOutput} minutes to answer questions.`)<n><n>    <n>    <n>    <n><n><n><n>    <n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n>Output:		composted    <n>Notes: <n><n>### Instruction:Complete the following program for this problem. Remember to use 'System.out.println(...)' or the equivalent when printing values.<n><n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>public class JavaProgram {<n>	public static void main (String[] args) {<n>		// Read the input values from the class.<n>		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);	<n>		char answer;<n>		int a,b,c;<n>		int totalsolution =0;<n>		System.out.println("enter a\n");<n>		a=input.nextInt();<n>        System.out.print("enter b\n");<n>        b=input.nextInt()+1;<n>        System.out<n>			.print("enter c\n");<n>        c=input.nextInt ()+1 ;<n>		// If the answer is in line with the 5 correct answers, then put them in <n>		// array list and find sum of all in that array list<n>		if(a=='a'||b=='b'||c=='c'||a=='nailed'||b=='composted'){<n>             totalsolution+=a;<n>            totalsolution+=b;<n>            totalsoition+=c;<n>	<n>		       System.out.println(totalsolution);<n>		 }<n>	<n><n>	}<n>}<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>Input : 123456<n>Output: 7890<n><n>Input : 200012345<n>Output: 656768798<n><n>Input: When would you be able to find your shadow at noon<n><n>Choices: A: burning in fire B: composting C: nailed to a board D: polished E: covered in dust<n>Output: Composted<n><n>### Instuctions:Complete the following program, using the class methods to complete the program. Hint: Write the class method and the main method in separate files. Remember to follow Java naming conventions.<n> <n><n><n><n><n>## Instructions:<n><ul><n><li
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where is basketball court likely to be outdoors? Choices:  A: high school gymnasium B: city C: park D: use E: los angeles<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: The sum of these numbers is 19. Which pair of numbers can be subtracted from the pair to obtain a sum of 0? Choices: A: 16 and -3 B: 15 and -4 C: 1,  0 + 18 D: 1, 0 – 18 – 17 – 16 + 15<n>Output: B<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```go<n>package main<n><n>import (<n>	"fmt"<n>)<n><n>func main() {<n>	fmt.Println(solution([]int{}))<n>}<n><n>// solution function return a []int type of Answer<n>func solution(nums []int) []int {<n>	// Write code here<n>	numberWithOne := []int{0}<n>	for _, aNumber := range nums {<n>		numberWithOne = append(numberWithOne, append([]int{0}, aNumber)...)<n>	}<n><n>	return numberWithOne<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Choices:  A: good health B: heart attacks C: relaxation D: rest E: fatigue<n>Output:		B<n><n>### Expected out: Above all, one of the most important elements of any type of programming is to focus on the problems that you are encountering and make small incremental progress.<n>### Examplification :<n><n>### First question.<n><n>### Second question.<n><n>## Exercise 13<n><n>### Instruction<n><n>* Write an algorithm( a.k.a computer program) that will add all odd numbers into an array.<n><n>### Exercise<n><n>* Algorithm:<n>        * Let us assume we have an array of integer numbers with elements in array denoted as: A[ ]<n><n>* 1. Initialise the sum variable as an accumulator, this will sum together all the elements in the array<n><n>```<n>    for(int firstValue=0; firstValue<=A.length-1; firstValue++)<n>    {<n>        sum+=31;<n>    }<n><n>    return sum;<n>```<n><n>* 2. Now loop through the array of elements and perform odd sum operation on each element in the array, save the result in the variable sum<n><n>```<n><n>* Initialise the sum variable and add 10 to it<n>    sum+=10;<n><n>    2. Add first array element to the previous result<n>    sum+=array[i];<n><n>    return sum<n>```<n>* 3. You should always follow the basic syntax in writing any programming language in order to make the code more efficient and understandable for readers.<n><n>* 4. In the above programming code, we have not provided any output. A good programmer should always remember that a good coder always adds appropriate output into the problem. <n><n>### Examination<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>* Write an Algorithm that will find and return the maximum value of an array<n>	<n>### Exercices<n><n>* Algorithm: <n>1. Initialise variable as the maximum value of the array.<n><n>```<n>    int max = A[ ];<n><n>2. Loop through the whole array<n>3. Compare the current value of A[2] with the initialised value of max<n>4. If the the A[2] > the max, then <n>5. increment the max variable by A[2]<n>6. end of Loop<n><n>max = A[2];<n>```<n><n>*
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where would you be going if using a parking lot near a roller coaster? Choices:  A: farm B: business district C: car D: amusement park E: urban area<n>Output:		D<n>Explanation/Hint: This question is a trick question. You are not going to the farm, you are going to the car, but the parking lot may be by the farm.<n><n>Input:  How many square feet are there in a room measuring 17 feet by 13 feet?<n>Output: 90 square feet<n><n>Input: The area of a rectangle can be calculated using (length x width). The equation can be written A = L x W. Where (A) = the area, (L) = length, (W) = width.<n><n>Input: The perimeter of a rectangle can be found by adding its sides together. The equation is P = 2L + 2W where P = the perimeter, L = length, W = width.<n><n><br /><n><img src=[[Images/mathgirl.jpg]]></img><img src="{{site.url}}/img/2020/3502.jpg"><img src="{{siteimg}}/2020-03-19/math2.png"><img src="{{img}}/{{site.url}}img/2021/191004/32396.png"><img src=[[Images]]/mathman.jpg></img>.<n>'''<n>math_game_10 = """"<n><n><n>"""<n><n>

At the end put in "done: true". At the very top put in "#include xxx".<n>-If there is only one question put in "input:". Do not put in "input: " but skip that part.<n>-After this part put in the question.<n>-You must include "done: true".<n>-If there are only 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 answers put in<n>        "input: <n>        choose a number between 1 and 5, inclusive"<n>-Otherwise put in <n>        "input: Choose one or more options"<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n><n>input: the time in Chicago is 4:00PM, and in New York it is 1:00PM. What is the time at the U.S.–Canada border (i.e. when people on both sides of the border have the exact same time)?<n>output: 3:00<n><n>The U.S. West Coast Time (UCT) and North American Central (NAC) time zones intersect at some point. We know that people in California can talk to people in Minnesota, and people in British Columbia can talk to people in Montana. So 4pm California time would map to 6pm UCT, 4pm in New York maps to 6pm NAC, and 6pm UCT maps to 8pm in Montana. As long as its not between 6pm and 8pm, people in Montana can talk to people in British Columbia, which means Montanas time must map to NAC at midnight. 9pm in California maps to midnight UCT. People can talk to people in the Mountain time zone any time that their times are within two hours of each other, so Californian times 3pm and 7pm maps to 1

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery store C: constructing models D: shed E: box<n>Output:		grocery store<n><n>This question is in honor of a very long, but very wonderful day with a very dear teacher/friend. I hope my work can honor as much love for me to her as you have for this program.<n><n>```  <n>    //input: Janet has 13 cards more than Brenda ( 13 > 5 = 8 more than Brenda)<n>    //Janet + 8 = 13 (card)<n>    //Brenda - 8 = 5 (card)<n>    JanetCards = ( Brenda - Janet ) //5 (card)<n>```<n>```<n>    //input: Pete walked 6 blocks from his house to school then 5 blocks from the school to the bus garage<n>    //walking between his house and the public school, 6 blocks<n>    //bus ride from school to garage, 20 blocks<n>    //home again, 5 blocks<n>    PeteMovement = ( fromHouse - toPublicSchool ) + ( fromPublicSchool to Garage ) + ( Garage to House ) <n>    //6(blocks) + 20 (blocks) + 5 (blocks)= 31 (totalBLOCKS)<n>    //blocks to miles and multiply: 3.2 (mil) = 31(blocks)= 100 (miles)<n>    PeteTraveled = ( fromHouse to publicSchool) ( Pete walked)<n>    //6(blk)<n>    PeteCars = (PeteTraveled + ( fromPublicScholl to toParking Lot) (from ParkingLot to Home) )<n>    //blocks<n>    PeteCarges = ( (walkingToGarage + school) (Pete walked)<n>                  ( fromGarage to School)<n>                  )<n>    PeteCards = ( (walkingHome from School+5) (Pete walked)) //5 (card)

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input:A boy rides his bike 5 miles north and then 5 miles south. He also rides 2 miles east and then 4 miles west. How far did the boy travel from his house?<n> Output: 18 miles<n><n>---<n><n>Instruction:Answer the questions in your own words.<n><n><n>###1<n><n>Both `p1 = p2 = p1` are true. However, none of their subexpressions are true. That is, the subexpressions for `p1` is not true when `p2` is true, and vice versa. This tells us that, even though `p1` and `p2` have the same structure, the values of the expressions are different. Because `b` is not 10, `p1 = 8` and `p2 = false` are true.<n><n>`p1` and `y` both evaluate to false, as `b` is not even close to being evenly divisible by 23. If `x` were `19`, however, because `b` is then closer to being evenly divisble by 23, `p1` and both `x` and `y` would still evaluate to false.<n><a id="multiple-choice-05"></a> <n><n>---<n><n>###2<n><n>This problem would have been easier if we had been allowed to see the definitions of the parameters. However, we do recognize that a `function` is a way to create values of given type using a set of instructions. So, in this case, it should be apparent that the call to `a.function1(p1)` is an attempt to create a value of type `boolean`. But how does the function know what `p1` refers to? It is the job of the `parameter-name` to tell it what to do. In this case, `parameter-name` is `p1` and the value passed in to the function is `undefined`, which is, of course, of no type at all.<n><n><a id="multiple-choice-06"></a> <n>---<n><n>## Multiple Choice Practice Session<n>#### 1.<n>Multiple choice practice session for JavaScript Programming questions. <n><n>  This program counts down from 10 to 1.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n>Output:		B<n><n>Instruction:Please answer the following question.  <n>When does the function "abs" return a negative value?  <n>A: when a negative number to "abs"  <n>B: if the number given is smaller than zero  <n>C: when an integer is input  <n>D: when the number is larger than zero<n>```<n><n># 0.2. Solution<n><n>[Go to solution and code](https://github.com/fengyiheng/leetcode/blob/main/medium/02_abs.py)<n><n># 01. Problem 腾讯考题<n><n>## 1. Abs(0)<n><n>```python<n>def abs(n):<n>    if n < 0:<n>        return 0<n>    else:<n>        return n<n>```<n><n>## 2. Abs() Returns Negative<n><n>```python<n># O(1)<n>def abs_2(n):<n>    return n if n > 0 else -n<n>```<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```<n>3. [ABS]([1, -2, -23], [0, 1, 5]):<n> [0, 0, 5]<n> -3<n> -2<n>  2<n>4. #0(n) 1 if n=0 return -1<n>def abs_3(n):<n>    n = n if n == 0 else -n # [1, 2, 3]  [1, 2]  [3]<n>    if n >= 0:<n>        n = abs(n)<n>    return n<n>5. [1, -5] 输出0，1； [2, 5] 输出1； [-1, -5]输出-1：<n>-5(1):6 < 5(2):0，return -5，不是[-5]<n> 5(2):12 < 5(2)：0，return -12<n>-5(-5)=5 5(2)=2，return 1<n>```<n><n>**总结**<n><n>腾论中写的`[abs(100), abs(abs(-100))]`<n><n>总结：<n><n>- 如果返回的第

How many males must there be if there is an equal chance that the council will consist of an odd number of men?<n>Output:3<n><n>#### Constraints:<n>No data/input should be displayed after entering the first answer.<n><n>#### Expected Result:<n><n>All the questions are to be displayed in a single line. Mara has 2x as many cards as Janat. How many cards do the have in all if Maras 40less than 150?"<n>answer = ["1.Janet 209","2.Brenda 159",  "3.Mara 110", "4.Mara 150"]<n><n>def display():<n>    print (q1+ ",")<n>    input= raw_input("input:")<n>    for i in range (0,4):<n>        print input,answer[i+1]<n><n>display()<n>```<n><n>##### Second step is to ask the user to choose the right answer :<n>```python<n>def show_inputs():<n>  qs = ["What is a loverlikely to want to do with the partner? The passengers are 41 men and 30 women. Whatis the probability that the next passengers to enter the plane is aleader"]<n>  for q in q

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n>Output:		C<n>---<n><n># **Write code to solve this problem**<n><n>```<n>from __future__ import print_function<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n>import sys<n>import os<n>import re<n><n><n>def check_range(low, high, arr):<n>  for i in arr:<n>    if i < low or i > high:<n>      return False<n>  return True<n><n><n>def run_check(low, high, n, rngs):<n>  total = 0<n>  for i in range(len(rngs)):<n>    if (low, high) in rngs[i]:<n>      total += i*(high - low + 1) + 1<n>  return total<n><n><n>def solve_brief(low, high,  n):<n>  # n = n = len(low)<n>  # rngs = rngs for one group that satisfy i <= j<n>  lens = []<n>  for i in sorted(range(len(low))):<n>    for j in sorted(range(i + 1, len(low)), reverse = True):<n>      if ((low[i],low[j]) in lens):<n>        lens.remove((low[i],low[-1]))<n>    rngs = [(low[i],low[(j + 1)% len(low)] if (j + 1) % len(low)!= i else high)]<n>    lens.append((low[i],lens[-1][1]) in lens)<n>    # print(repr(n,rngs,i,lens))<n>    total = run_check(low[i],high, n, rnges)<n>    # print("lens before", lens)<n>    lens = []<n>    total += total if i in lens<n>    if len(rngs) < n:<n>      print("Can't find sufficient ranges")<n>      return "Can't find sufficient rngs"<n>    if i >= n:<n>      total += run_check(low[(n - 1) + 2], high, n - (n - 1), rngs)<n>      print("lens after", lens)<n>      return total<n>  return "not enough test cases or errors!"<n><n><n>N = int

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n>Output:		E<n><n>Input: In a survey, 62% of the kids said they preferred reading, but 80% said they preferred TV. What percent of these kids are more likely to prefer reading to watching TV? Choices: A. 38% B. 29% Choices: C.41% D.28%<n>Output: 41%<n><n>### Step-1:<n>The only way to solve the first question is using the PEMDAS rules as there is only one question and there is only one operation you will need to solve this problem.<n><n>PEMDAS order of operations : Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction.<n><n>Step-2:<n>The only way of solving the second question is using the order of operations. We must consider the exponents first and then the multiplication, addition, multiplication and so on.<n><n>Step-3:<n>We first need to formulate our problem as an equation and then find the answer 41% as it is the only answer which uses all of the facts in the problem. We first look for the fact that 80% of the kids like TV and there are 62% who liked reading. However we don't use that fact. Instead, we use the fact that 8% of those who prefer TV over reading and those who prefer reading over TV. Finally, the answer comes as 41%.<n><n>Step-4:<n>The only way is to write the question as an equation and then apply the order of operations to arrive at the final answer.<n><n>Step-5:<n>The only answer for this question is 0.5 because there is no difference between the cards Janet has and the cards brenda has. Hence, when we multiply both 9 and 2 the value does not change as their sum remains the same.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n>Output:		<n><n>Input:Which of the following lists contains only even numbers. Choices:  A;2,4,6,8,10 B : 2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16 C: 3,5,7,9,11,13,15 D: 5,11,17 E : 6,12,20<n>Output:<n><n>#### Solution: <n>Let's assume Janet has (n) cards, Brenda has (m) cards; and Mara has (100-n)/2 cards<n><n>### Input - Janet has 9 (9 cards) more than Brenda.<n><n>If Janet has n + 9 cards, Brenda(m) + 5 cards<n><n>Mara has (100 -n)/2 - 5 cards<n><n>Therefore, <n><n>n + m = m + (100 - n)/2 + 9 + 5,<n>m - n = 100 - m + m + 9, <n>n = 81 - m, <n>n + m + 5 = n + m + (105-n)/2<n><n>We can conclude if m > n, the answer is 211. <n><n><n>### Input: Pete walked 2 blocks from his house to his bus garage in Houston, He rode the bus 95 blocks to the post office. Pete returned the same way. How far did Pete walk in all?<n>Input-Pete walked 5 blocks than rode 20 miles and came home the same way<n><n>So, if pete walked 5 blocks it means he has covered a distance of 5 miles and then his total distance covered must be (20 - 5) miles or 15 miles<n><n>### Input-Where is a microphone likely to be at a stock market event? <n><n>We can conclude that a microphone boom could be present at a concert(choices A and B), a recording studio(choices C and D) <n><n>We can't eliminate choices C and D<n><n>### Input : <n>In choices A B C D E, we can eliminate choices A, B, D which do not fit in the given requirements, because they contain even numbers

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n>Output:		relaxation<n><n>### Solution:Please implement below three instructions sequentially to get the answer.<n><n>```python<n>def getCards(num1,num2,num3):<n>  return num1+num2-num3<n>def getMoney(num1,num11,num21,num31):<n>  return num31-num21<n>num1 = int(input("Input 1: \n"))<n>num2 = int(input("input 2: \n"))<n><n>num3 = int(input("num 3: "\n"))<n><n>ans=getCards(num1+num2- num3,9,150)<n>ans<n><n>output="Answer is : "+str(ans)<n>print(output)<n><n>num12 = int(input("\nInput 12: \n"))     num22 = int(input(<n>"Input 12: "<n>))        num32 = int(input(".num 3: "))<n>ans=getCords(num12,num32)<n>ans<n><n>ans=getMoney(num12,12,num3)<n>ans<n>"""<n><n>output1= f'.Input 1: {ans}'<n>input(output1)<n><n>num13 = int(input(f".Input 13: \n"))<n>input(f"Input number 14: {num13}")<n>num23 = int(input(".Input 14: "))<n>input(f".Input number 15: "+str(num23))<n>num33 = int(input(.num 15: "))<n>"""                  <n><n>num1 = int()<n>num2 = int()<n>num3 = int()<n>num12 = 0<n>num22 = 0<n><n>num32 = 0<n># num1, num2 and num3 take input<n>while num1 <= 30:<n> num12 = num12+num1<n> num1 = int()<n>if num32 == 0:<n>    ans1 = (num12 - num32) // 4<n>    num4 = ans1 * 4<n>    num3 = num3 + num12 - num4- num32<n>    # ans<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n>Output:		None<n><n>###Explanation:<n> 1. Answer B<n> 2. Answer E<n> 3. This question is un-solvable, you can't tell that they celebrate by going places.<n><n>### Instruction:This question might look familiar to you, It looks like the 7th question.<n><n>### What's the difference this question and last question?<n>Well, the last question is more interesting.<n><n>###Instruction:Find the word that's a pronoun. <n>A pronoun is a word that takes the place of a noun.  <n>In this question. We look for a word that takes the  place of the person. We should find the noun and the pronoun.<n><n>###Expalnation:<n>Pronoun in the picture, the answer is He.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n>Output:		E<n><n><table><n><tr><n>	<td>B</td><n>	<td bgcolor="blue"><n>		<p id="code-a">var n = 0, i = 0;for (var i in a) { if (a.hasOwnProperty (i)) { if (i in a) { n = 1 } else { n = 0 } } } if (n == 0) { b = a.keys ().reduce (function (prev, curr) { return curr <= prev? b : a[curr]; }, null); } else { b = a; } } return b;</p><n>	</td><n></tr><n><tr> <n>		<td bgcolor="#f5f5f5"><n>			<p><n>			Write code to add each element of an array to a new array<n>			</p><n>		</td><n>		<td><n>			<ul> <li>Add 1 element to 1st array, if the new array is less long add all the elements to a third array! Write a function that will return the new array after all the arrays have been added together</li> <li>The array lengths may be different in every iteration</li></ul><n>		</tr><n>		<tr><n>			<n>			<td>C</td><n>	</tr><n></table><n><n># Challenge<n>- <n>

The program takes an integer, and if the number is greater than 3, it subtracts 3 from the number, and then adds that value to the last three values that it has calculated.<n><n>### Code<n>The following code is brenda.py<n><n>```python<n>def main():<n>    print ('What Time Is It Time is at what Time Is it Time Is It Time Is at Time Is It Time?')<n>    number = int(input('Enter a number to calculate.> '))<n>    while number <= 3:<n>        sum = sum+number<n>        number = number + 3<n>    while number >= 3 and number < 0:<n>        sum = (sum+number)/6<n>        number = sum-3<n>        print('What Time Is It Time? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Get each set of inputs separately, as the number of cards is changing with each new question.<n># <n># To keep track of Janet's current number of cards, sum a variable which is equal to the number of cards already.<n># Add the number of cards that Brenda has to Janet's current total number of cards.<n># Use Brenda's input as the variable that will increase with each iteration of the for loop.<n><n># For Janet's new number of cards, multiply by 2 to get Mara's number of cards. <n># Now, as the number of Janet's cards is known, multiple Janet's new total by the number of Brenda's.<n><n># Add this to the total cards variable.<n># The same formula is used to compute total cards for second question of multiple choice.<n><n># Add Mara's total to the total cards variable, to get the total cards<n><n># For the second multiple choice problem, the same formula is used.<n><n># To keep track Mara's number, use a variable equal to the number of brenda cards.<n><n># Use this variable in the multiplication formula.<n><n># To calculate Mara's total number of cards, divide the total cards variable by this value.<n><n># To compute a total cards variable, multiply the answer to the first question by the total cards variable. Set int total_cards equal to this new value. Add total_cards to this new variable.<n><n># Test the number by dividing it by 20. If it is equal to 20, it is equal to the correct answer<n><n>if total_cards == 20:<n>   print("The output is 20")<n>else:<n>   print(total_cards)<n><n># Cards with no choices provided as answer: <n><n># Test the following conditions if any of them are met, the answer is the first choice.<n><n>if total_card == 1:<n>    print("A

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:She was bad at dancing, so what basic skill did the instructor teach her? Choices:  A: euphoria B: rhythmic movement C: music D: moving body E: having fun<n>Output:		D<n>### Code :<n>```<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>class Solution {<n>    public static String stringToNumber(String s) {<n>        StringBuilder buff = new StringBuilder();<n>        int i = 0, pos = 0, idx = 0, c = 0;<n><n>        while(i < s.length()) {<n>            c = s.charAt(i);<n>            if (c >= '0' && c <= '9')<n>                idx = c - '0';<n>            else if (c >= 'A' && c <= 'Z')<n>                idx = (char) (c-'A'+10);<n>            else if (Character.isDigit(c))<n>                throw new NumberFormatException();<n>            else <n>                buff.append(c);<n>            i++;<n>        }<n><n>        return buff.toString();<n>    }<n><n>    public String solution(String[] A, String[] B) {<n><n>        if(A.length < B.length)<n>            return "Cannot be done";<n><n>        Stack<Integer> stackA = new Stack<>();<n>        Stack<Integer[]> stackB = new Stack<>();<n><n>        for(int i = 0; i < A.length; i++)<n>            stackA.push(new Integer(A[i]));<n><n>        for(i = 0; i <= B.length; i++) {<n>            if(stackA.peek() > 0) {<n>                stackB.push(new Integer[] {0, stackA.pop()});<n>                stackB.pop();<n>            } else {<n>                stackB = new Stack();<n>                if(i == B.length)<n>                    break;<n>            }<n>        }<n>   <n>        return stringToNumber(stackB.peek()[1]+"+"+stringToNumber(stackB[1][1])+stackB.last().toString());<n>     }<n>}<n>```<n>### Test :<n><n>```<n>02:51:25 2. Brenda had 9 more cards than Janet. Mara had twice as many cards as Brenda, yet Mara had 40 fewer cards than 150. How many cards were there altogether?<n>Input:9, 60, 110, 15
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. (year -- year ago)<n>Output: 4<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:How should we answer questions that can have more than one answer?<n><n>I have found that in addition to having many multiple answer questions (as opposed to the multiple choice) it is quite common for some non-multiple choice questions to have more than ONE correct answer... For example..in Question 7 of the above example...A person may go free if they confess and the prosecution is very convincing. However..in reality...the person is most likely NOT going to get free. You answer choices C, D and or E are not the real answer so in this case we would have used Answer B as the "correct" answer.<n><n><n><n>

This difference was the same for both persons.<n><n>What do A and B represent? Choices A: A represents positive test, B represents negative test<n>Output: The correct choices are: B represents positive test, A represents negative test<n><n>#Author : Bruno<n>#Solution :https://coderanch/faq/90995/<n>#Comment : No comment<n><n><n>#Author :Jess<n>#Solution : https://coderanch.c0m/faq/265777/<n>#Comment : This was an open-ended question<n><n>#Author :Ryan<n>#Solution : <n>#Author :Judy<n>#Solution :<n>#Author :Hai<n>#Solution :No Comment<n><n>147. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n>Output:		E<n>How To Write An Algorithm For This Question:<n><n>input: the number of words in each sentence<n>input: the words that make up the sentences to practice with<n>output: the number of times each word appears in the sentence<n><n>instructions: if both words are one or two letters long, only the last two letters are needed, so the last three letters of "i am" would be the sequence of the characters i, am<n><n>1 is inputted. <n><n>input is then divided by 5, so 1/5 will equal 0.2.<n><n>0.2 is then converted to a double, which equals 1.02.<n><n><n>1.23456 is then 320<n>1.23 is then 313<n>1.2 is then 62<n>1.02 is then 100<n><n><n>0.2345 is then 51.7333<n>This is repeated untill the number of words reaches 0.<n><n>output is put into the correct location, after the double,<n>so the last three letters of an 20 letter sentence have 50 in the output<n><n><n>(This is the correct algorithm)<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the questions below to complete the exercises.<n>

Write your data dictionary in Google Docs.<n><n>###  Write a statement about each function.<n>|Function|Description|<n>|:---:|:---|<n>|`gcd`|The `gcd` function returns the greatest common divisor between two numbers|<n>|`isEven`|The `isEven` function checks if a number is even or odd.|<n>|`getEvenFactorial`|The `getEvenFactor` function checks what the product of the divisors of an even number is.|<n>|`sum`|The `sum1` function finds the sum of numbers in an array.|<n>|`median`|The `median` function finds the middle number, given an array.|<n><n>-<n>###  Write the function definitions.<n>- Use your data dictionary as a reference.<n><n>### Instruction: Test your functions on the following input. Write your code in the `code` environment.<n><n>```Javascript<n><n>```<n><n>### Instructions: Once you've written your code, type in the input, click "Submit", and your answers will display on the screen. How much does the dirt weigh?<n>Output: 12 oz<n><n>Input: There are 10,007,168 ways of arranging 6 chocolate easter eggs in a round box. How many of these arrangements can be done in such way that if you move one egg from position A to position B, no egg is in the same position as it originally was?<n>Output: 49323<n><n>The above problems are from [here](https://docs.adventureswithcoding.com/lesson-1-counting/)<n><n>### Instruction:Write a program that will solve this following problem.<n><n>Input:There are n different numbers. What is the lowest number in the set?<n>    Output: Returns the lowest number in the list<n><n>    Input: 4<n>    Output: returns 1<n><n>### Solution (in Ruby):<n>```<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <vector><n>#include <string><n>#include <algorithm><n>using namespace std;<n><n>void printArr(vector <int> arr, string res) {<n>    for (int i=0; i<arr.size(); i++)<n>        cout <<arr[i] <<''<< i+1 <<" \t";<n>    for (int j=0; j<arr.size(); j++)<n>        cout << " -> " << arr[j] << '\n';<n>    for (int k=2; k<j; k++) {<n>        cout << "\t"<< "MATCH " <<res;<n>        swap(arr[k], arr[j]);<n>        printArr(arr, res);<n>        swap(arr, arr[j]);<n>    }<n>}<n><n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    int nb, arr[1000];<n>    cin >> nb;<n><n>    for(int i=0;i<nb;i++) {<n>        cin >> arr[i];<n>    }<n>    vector<int>vect;<n>    for(int a=0;a<nb;a++) {<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n>Output:		Fragile is the answer we choose.<n>   <n>### Multiple Choice Solution:<n><n>    Input: Janet has 21 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as  many cards as Janet.  In order  to subtract and remove the variables the question needs to be rearranged. Janet does Janet - Brenda = number_of_cards.  Number of cards = { Janet - Brenda } -  Mara.   Mara has twice that number of cards which would be { 40 x 2 } = 80.  To find out how many cards Mara has subtract 150 from { 40 x  2 } = 88 cards = 80.<n>      In order to find a combined total we need to find the difference between  the two largest numbers or the difference of the two differences. 211 =  Janet -  Brenda - Mara <n><n>    Input: Pete walked  (10 - 10) blocks from his house to  the bus garage in  Houston.  He   rode the bus  100 blocks to the post  office to get some stumps.  Later, he came home  the  same way. How many  blocks  did  Pete travel in all?<n>      This question is almost the same as the prior one. Since the answer is the same as prior we will simply find the difference between the numbers we get from either prior or here<n>      blocks traveled = (20 - 10 )*(100 - 100) = 200.<n><n>    Input: Glass that hasn't  been treated to be extra  strong  is what? Choices :  A: weak  B: fragile  C: forceless  D: regular  E: flimsy   <n>  Glass that hasn' weak  flimsy but fragile meaning forceless because it breaks easily.  Strength is relative to the circumstances applied to its resistance to breakage.  If for example a rock is used to break it, and compared to it, it would be weak.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input:Which of the following animals is most likely to have all hair? Choices: 1: BIRD 2: ELEPHANT, GIRAFFE 3: HORSE, FISH 4: DOLPHIN, PIG E: NONE OF THE ABOVE<n>Output: A<n>Which of the following is a kind of triangle?<n>Answer choices:<n>A. Square B. Right b. E Triangle C. Isosceles.<n><n>**SOLUTION:** The input "9 cards more than Branda" means that Janet already has more cards than Brenda then Mara has twice the number of cards than Janet. So it can be said that Mara has, 9*2= 18 more than Brenda. Now the input says that Mara has 41-150= 110 more cards than 150. But 110-41= 69, so Mara has one more card than 69. Putting this extra card in the collection of the remaining 211. So answer of the question is 211.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n>Output:		B<n><n><n><n>### Partial Function Code:<n><n>```python<n>class solution(object):<n>    def solve(self, n):<n>        """<n>        :type n: int<n>        :rtype: int<n>        """<n>        print("Hello")<n>        ans = (n ** 3) * (n ** 2) * n<n>        print(ans)<n>        return ans<n>def main():<n>    n = int(input()) <n>    sol1 = solution()<n>    print(sol1.solve(n))<n>main()<n>```<n><n>### My Code:<n><n>```c++<n><n>class Solution {<n> public:<n>   int solution(int n) {<n>      if (n < 1){<n>         return 1;<n>      }<n>      return n - (n - 1) - (n - 2) - (n -3)<n>   }<n>};<n><n>int main() {<n>    Solution sol;<n>    int ans;<n>    cin<n>        >> ans;<n>    printf("%d", sol.solution(ans));<n>    return 0;<n>}<n>```<n>
